quotes.Quote Content: But release me from my bands / With the help of your good hands...
Time's glory is to calm contending kings, / To unmask falsehood, and bring truth to light.
Blese be the man that spares these stones / And curst be he that moves my bones
What cannot be eschewed must be embraced
Beauty itself doth of itself persuade / The eyes of men without an orator.
That deep torture may be called a hell, / When more is felt than one hath power to tell.
On a day — alack the day! — / Love, whose month is ever May...
quotes.Data Source: *Sonnets to Sundry Notes of Music*, II

quotes.Quote Content: Crabbed age and youth cannot live together: / Youth is full of pleasure, age is full of care
I gyve unto my wief my second best bed with the furniture
Good frend for Jesus sake forbeare / To digg the dust encloased heare...
Now is the winter of our discontent / Made glorious summer by this sun of York.
Off with his head!
A horse! A horse! My kingdom for a horse!
What light through yonder window breaks?
quotes.Data Source: *Romeo and Juliet*, Act II, scene ii

quotes.Quote Content: What's in a name? That which we call a rose, / By any other name would smell as sweet.
quotes.Data Source: *Romeo and Juliet*, Act II, scene ii

quotes.Quote Content: O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo?
quotes.Data Source: *Romeo and Juliet*, Act II, scene ii

quotes.Quote Content: The course of true love never did run smooth.
quotes.Data Source: *A Midsummer Night's Dream*, Act I, scene i

quotes.Quote Content: Lord, what fools these mortals be!
quotes.Data Source: *A Midsummer Night's Dream*, Act III, scene ii

quotes.Quote Content: Love looks not with the eyes, but with the mind, / And therefore is wing'd Cupid painted blind.
quotes.Data Source: *A Midsummer Night's Dream*, Act I, scene i

quotes.Quote Content: If to do were as easy as to know what were good to do, chapels had been churches, and poor men’s cottages princes’ palaces.
quotes.Data Source: *The Merchant of Venice*, Act I, scene ii

quotes.Quote Content: All that glisters is not gold.
quotes.Data Source: *The Merchant of Venice*, Act II, scene vii

quotes.Quote Content: I am a Jew. Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions...
quotes.Data Source: *The Merchant of Venice*, Act III, scene i

quotes.Quote Content: The better part of valour is discretion; in the which better part I have saved my life.
quotes.Data Source: *Henry IV, Part 1*, Act V, scene iv

quotes.Quote Content: A man can die but once.
quotes.Data Source: *Henry IV, Part 2*, Act III, scene ii

quotes.Quote Content: Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown.
quotes.Data Source: *Henry IV, Part 2*, Act III, scene i

quotes.Quote Content: As merry as the day is long.
quotes.Data Source: *Much Ado About Nothing*, Act II, scene i

quotes.Quote Content: Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more, / Men were deceivers ever...
quotes.Data Source: *Much Ado About Nothing*, Act II, scene iii

quotes.Quote Content: Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.
quotes.Data Source: *Much Ado About Nothing*, Act III, scene i

quotes.Quote Content: Beware the ides of March.
Men at some time are masters of their fates: / The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, / But in ourselves...
Cowards die many times before their deaths; / The valiant never taste of death but once.
Cry 'Havoc!,' and let slip the dogs of war.
Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears; / I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him...
All the world's a stage, / And all the men and women merely players...
quotes.Data Source: *As You Like It*, Act II, scene vii

quotes.Quote Content: The fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be a fool.
quotes.Data Source: *As You Like It*, Act V, scene i

quotes.Quote Content: Neither a borrower nor a lender be; / For loan oft loses both itself and friend...
Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice.
The time is out of joint: O cursed spite, / That ever I was born to set it right!
There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.
What a piece of work is a man! / How noble in reason, how infinite in faculty!...
To be or not to be, that is the question.
If music be the food of love, play on.
Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em.
Reputation is an idle and most false imposition; oft got without merit and lost without deserving.
Of one that lov'd not wisely but too well.
We have seen better days.
quotes.Data Source: *Timon of Athens*, Act IV, scene ii

quotes.Quote Content: Nothing can come of nothing.
How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is / To have a thankless child!
I am a man, / More sinn'd against than sinning.
The barge she sat in, like a burnish'd throne, / Burnt on the water.
quotes.Data Source: *Antony and Cleopatra*, Act II, scene ii

quotes.Quote Content: Come what come may, / Time and the hour runs through the roughest day.
